thread.title: H.S. girls soccer: Northern Highlands reaches BCT final
thread.title_full: H.S. girls soccer: Northern Highlands reaches BCT final

title: H.S. girls soccer: Northern Highlands reaches BCT final
text:
Unbeaten Northern Highlands, which needed a second-half burst, celebrates its semifinal win over Ridgewood on Sunday. 
ORADELL — The frustration all but silenced Tara Madigan. 
The normally vocal and fiery Northern Highlands coach crouched on the River Dell sideline, reduced to speechlessness, during a scoreless first half Sunday. 
The apparent displeasure in her eyes masked by a pair of sleek black sunglasses, Madigan was mystified as her high-powered Highlanders, averaging more than four goals per game, were failing to execute the game plan in the Bergen County girls soccer tournament semifinals against fourth-seeded Ridgewood. 
"And usually that’s worse when you don’t hear me," Madigan said afterward with a laugh. "At half, we talked about how we had 40 minutes left and how if they wanted to be playing next weekend, they had better start doing something." 
And do something they did. 
Showing off, yet again, its quick-strike ability and tendency to take over games — particularly in second halves — top-seeded Northern Highlands struck four times after the break, each goal seemingly more adept than the last, for a 4-0 win to advance to Saturday’s final. 
"Maybe working on my pregame speeches is what I need to do," Madigan joked, as her team improved to 16-0, won its 22nd consecutive game and set up the fourth straight installment of Northern Highlands against Immaculate Heart in the county final. "Having four goals with four different scorers is just an example of what our team is like this year. 
"We’re not focusing on any one player, we have a lot of contributing factors." 
Georgetown-bound Casey Richards being one of them, as the senior midfielder broke the scoreless tie Sunday with 29:12 left off a nifty inside dish from Amanda Pook. 
Moments later, Siena-bound Ariel Somple sliced through the middle of the Ridgewood defense, chasing down and depositing an entry pass sent into the box from Madison Kahn. 
A nail-biting scoreless tie turned into a comfortable two-goal lead in a span of 27 seconds. 
"When we see its 0-0 or its close at half, we just want to come out stronger and score as many goals as we can right away in the second half," Pook said. "That’s our mentality." 
Notre Dame-bound junior Eva Hurm later one-timed a long-range and pinpoint right-to-left cross to the far post from Fordham-bound defender Morgan Busacca with 14:34 left, and freshman Elizabeth Peebles capitalized on Richards’ brilliant left-to-right cross with 5:42 left for her first career score to cap Highlands’ second-half outburst. 
"It did take us a while to get going," said Somple, with 12 goals this season. "They played such a high line that we had to start playing balls over the top. Once the first one goes in, it seems like we play with more confidence. We know we can put balls in the back of the net, but we just had to start executing better." 
The execution led to another showdown with IHA with a county championship on the line. Highlands says it has moved on from last year’s 1-0 defeat to the Blue Eagles that snapped its 88-game unbeaten streak — and the results have indicated as much — but many of the players who experienced last year’s streak-stopping heartbreaker will be taking the field again Saturday. 
The frustration now long dissipated as the sun set at River Dell on Sunday, Madigan spoke eagerly about the upcoming opportunity. 
"We’re excited to be going back," she said. "We’ve got a lot of seniors in our group and it’s great for them. If the crowd and atmosphere are anything like last year, it will be a fantastic setup. We’re looking forward to it."
